Model SIM

01_Model_SIM.Rmd

Please find below guidelines how godley package can be used to create model SIM — the simplest model with government money described by Wynne Godley and Marc Lavoie in Chapter 3 in Monetary Economics. An Integrated Approach to Credit, Money, Income, Production and Wealth.

library(godley)

Base scenario

First you need to create empty SFC model:

# Create empty model
model_sim <- create_model(name = "SFC SIM")
#> Empty model created

Next you have to add variables:

# Add variables
model_sim <- model_sim |>
  add_variable("C_d", desc = "Consumption demand by households") |>
  add_variable("C_s", desc = "Consumption supply") |>
  add_variable("G_s", desc = "Government supply") |>
  add_variable("H_h", desc = "Cash money held by households") |>
  add_variable("H_s", desc = "Cash money supplied by the government") |>
  add_variable("N_d", desc = "Demand for labor") |>
  add_variable("N_s", desc = "Supply of labor") |>
  add_variable("T_d", desc = "Taxes, demand") |>
  add_variable("T_s", desc = "Taxes, supply") |>
  add_variable("Y", desc = "Income = GDP") |>
  add_variable("Yd", desc = "Disposable income of households") |>
  add_variable("alpha1", init = 0.6, desc = "Propensity to consume out of income") |>
  add_variable("alpha2", init = 0.4, desc = "Propensity to consume out of wealth") |>
  add_variable("theta", init = 0.2, desc = "Tax rate") |>
  add_variable("G_d", init = 20, desc = "Government demand") |>
  add_variable("W", init = 1, desc = "Wage rate")

You also have to add equations:

# Add equations
model_sim <- model_sim |>
  add_equation("C_s = C_d", desc = "Consumption") |>
  add_equation("G_s = G_d") |>
  add_equation("T_s = T_d") |>
  add_equation("N_s = N_d") |>
  add_equation("Yd = W * N_s - T_s") |>
  add_equation("T_d = theta * W * N_s") |>
  add_equation("C_d = alpha1 * Yd + alpha2 * H_h[-1]") |>
  add_equation("H_s = G_d - T_d + H_s[-1]") |>
  add_equation("H_h = Yd - C_d + H_h[-1]") |>
  add_equation("Y = C_s + G_s") |>
  add_equation("N_d = Y/W") |>
  add_equation("H_s = H_h", desc = "Money equilibrium", hidden = TRUE)

Now you can simulate model (in this example for the next 100 periods using Newton method):

# Simulate model
model_sim <- simulate_scenario(model_sim, scenario = "baseline", max_iter = 350, periods = 100, 
                               hidden_tol = 0.1, tol = 1e-08, method = "Newton")
#> Model prepared successfully
#> Simulating scenario baseline (1 of 1)
#> Scenario(s) successfully simulated

Based on calculated simulation you can display results for desired set of variables:

# Plot results
plot_simulation(model = model_sim, scenario = c("baseline"), from = 1, to = 50, 
                expressions = c("Y", "C_d", "G_s"))

Note: In above example new pipe operator was applied. It does not work in older R versions (before R 4.1).

Shock scenario

With godley package you can simulate how a shock will affect the base scenario. In this example you will implement a permanent increase in government expenditures.

First you need to create empty shock object:

# Create empty shock
shock_sim <- create_shock()
#> Shock object created

Next you need to add appropriate equation:

# Add shock equation with increased government expenditures
shock_sim <- add_shock(shock_sim, equation = "G_d = 25", 
                       desc = "Increase in government expenditures", start = 5, end = 50)

Later you need to create the shock scenario:

# Create new scenario with this shock
model_sim <- add_scenario(model_sim, name = "expansion", origin = "baseline", 
                          origin_period = 1, shock = shock_sim)

Now you can simulate new shock scenario:

# Simulate shock
model_sim <- simulate_scenario(model_sim, scenario = "expansion", max_iter = 350, periods = 100, 
                               hidden_tol = 0.1, tol = 1e-08, method = "Newton")
#> Simulating scenario expansion (1 of 1)
#> Scenario(s) successfully simulated

You can also compare results from shock and base scenarios:

# Plot results
plot_simulation(model = model_sim, scenario = c("baseline", "expansion"), from = 1, to = 50, 
                expressions = c("Y"))
plot_simulation(model = model_sim, scenario = c("baseline", "expansion"), from = 1, to = 50, 
                expressions = c("C_d"))
plot_simulation(model = model_sim, scenario = c("baseline", "expansion"), from = 1, to = 50, 
                expressions = c("G_s"))

References

More information about model SIM can be found in Chapter 3 in Monetary Economics. An Integrated Approach to Credit, Money, Income, Production and Wealth.
